title: The Variant Hunters: Inside South Africa’s Effort to Stanch Dangerous Mutations
content: Scientists in a cutting-edge laboratory do part of the work. Local health workers on foot do the rest.

title: Inside a Sequencing Lab on the Front Lines of America’s Search for Omicron
content: More states are finding cases of the new variant. Tracking its spread, experts say, is key to understanding what threat it poses.

title: Upstate New York Hospitals Are Overwhelmed as Covid Cases Surge
content: Health care officials say a “perfect storm” of new Covid cases, staff shortages and filled nursing homes has created a crisis.

title: In the Michigan Shooting, What Is the School’s Responsibility?
content: Oxford High School let Ethan Crumbley back into a classroom despite concerns about his behavior. Now, legal experts are asking why — and whether officials should be held accountable.

more_info.byline: By Dana Goldstein, Stephanie Saul and Sophie Kasakove
org_facet: Oxford High School (Oxford Charter Township, Mich)

title: Parents of Michigan Shooting Suspect Arrested in Detroit, Police Say
content: The couple were charged after officials said their son carried out the shootings using a handgun his parents had bought for him.

more_info.byline: By Gerry Mullany, Eduardo Medina and Sophie Kasakove
org_facet: Oxford High School (Oxford Charter Township, Mich)

title: The Abortion I Didn’t Have
content: I never thought about ending my pregnancy. Instead, at 19, I erased the future I had imagined for myself.

title: Voting Battles of 2022 Take Shape as G.O.P. Crafts New Election Bills
content: Republicans plan to carry their push to reshape the nation’s electoral system into next year, with Democrats vowing to oppose them but holding few options in G.O.P.-led states.

title: Fearing a Repeat of Jan. 6, Congress Eyes Changes to Electoral Count Law
content: Members of the special House committee investigating the Capitol riot are among those arguing for an overhaul of a more than century-old statute enacted to address disputed elections.

more_info.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Nick Corasaniti

title: Big Contracts, Big Buyouts, Big Pressure: College Football Coaches Hit the Jackpot
content: Brian Kelly will earn at least $9 million a year at L.S.U., which is paying its old coach almost $17 million to step aside. Top universities have become steppingstones to other top gigs.

title: At Jackson State, the ‘Prime Effect’ Reverberates
content: In his first full season as the football coach, Deion Sanders has guided the Tigers to the conference championship game and energized a community. He says he’s just getting started.

title: U.S. Intelligence Sees Russian Plan for Possible Ukraine Invasion
content: An invasion force could include 175,000 troops, but U.S. officials stress that President Vladimir V. Putin’s intentions remain unclear.

des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

title: Public Displays of Resignation: Saying ‘I Quit’ Loud and Proud
content: People aren’t just leaving their jobs. They are broadcasting it.

title: The Weekender
content: A climbing award that may be a winner’s last. Also in this edition: the great “West Side Story” debate, and a look at luxury senior housing.

title: The New York Times News Quiz, December 3, 2021
content: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: How Fast Can You Skydive? These Athletes Are Racing to Earth.
content: Average amateur skydivers can reach up to 120 miles per hour. Speed skydivers aim to reach speeds above 300 m.p.h.

title: Honeybees Survived for Weeks Under Volcano Ash After Canary Islands Eruption
content: For roughly 50 days, thousands of honeybees sealed themselves in their hives, away from deadly gas, and feasted on honey. “It is a very empowering story,” one entomologist said.

title: When Did Spotify Wrapped Get So Chatty?
content: This year’s data dump from the streaming music service leaned heavily on contemporary buzzwords and slang — and inspired many, many memes.

title: A Way to Break the Cycle of Poverty
content: Intervening in children’s lives early can help break the cycle of intergenerational poverty.

title: Josh Hawley and the Republican Obsession With Manliness
content: The Missouri senator is tapping into something real — a widespread, politically potent anxiety about young men that is already helping the right.

title: The Supreme Court Should Reject Arizona’s Death Penalty Gambit
content: Two Arizona men who were appointed ineffective lawyers landed on death row. If Arizona has its way, the Supreme Court will close an already narrow avenue for relief.

title: What Biden Isn’t Saying About Trump’s Positive Covid Test
content: The former president’s reckless behavior deserves more attention.

title: I Was the Governor of Montana. My Fellow Democrats, You Need to Get Out of the City More.
content: It’s time to ditch the grand ideological narratives and talk to voters about their real needs.

title: Can a Michigan Football Game Make Me Happy Forever?
content: The Euphoria of a Big Win, Explained.

title: Behind Low Vaccination Rates Lurks a More Profound Social Weakness
content: Vaccine hesitancy reflects a transformation of people’s core beliefs about what we owe each other.

more_info.byline: By Anita Sreedhar and Anand Gopal

title: The Supreme Court Gaslights Its Way to the End of Roe
content: The only question is, how will they explain it?

title: The Metaverse Is Coming, and the World Is Not Ready for It
content: The geopolitical consequences may be radical.

title: Wonking Out: Money Isn’t Everything
content: No, not even in macroeconomics.

title: Believe It or Not, I Like Some Things in Our Progressive Era
content: It’s good to acknowledge our past and our diversity.

title: Why the Fed Chair Won’t Call Inflation ‘Transitory’ Anymore
content: Jerome Powell has lost patience with the pace of the rebound in labor force participation.

title: Parenting’s Hard. Join Us and the Comedian Michelle Buteau to Vent.
content: As we approach another pandemic holiday season, let’s laugh about the “joys” of parenting, at a Dec. 8 virtual event hosted by Jessica Grose of The Times’s Opinion newsletter on parenting.

title: In Africa, Dealing With Vaccine Challenges and the Omicron Variant
content: Vaccine shortages and skepticism, and rewarding countries for discovering variants. Also: Happiness and politics; unwanted children; beware of psychedelics.

title: I Was Adopted. I Know the Trauma It Can Inflict.
content: What Amy Coney Barrett doesn’t realize is that adoption is often infinitely more difficult, expensive, dangerous and potentially traumatic than terminating a pregnancy in its early stages.

title: The Great Resignation Won’t Last Forever
content: Americans are waiting for the right opportunity to jump back into the work force.

title: Omicron Is Here. Should You Cancel Your Trip?
content: Most people have become used to making health-risk assessments during the pandemic, but that doesn’t make the decision about whether to travel or cancel easier — especially with a new variant circulating.

title: Best TV Shows of 2021
content: From Bo Burnham to “We Are Lady Parts,” the best in television this year offered ingenuity, humor, defiance and hope.

more_info.byline: By James Poniewozik, Mike Hale and Margaret Lyons

title: Thefts, Always an Issue for Retailers, Become More Brazen
content: In recent months, robberies have been more visible, with several involving large groups rushing into stores and coming out with armloads of goods.

more_info.byline: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari

title: What Happened to Amazon’s Bookstore?
content: A 2011 thriller was supposed to cost $15. One merchant listed it at $987, with a 17th-century publication date. That’s what happens in a marketplace where third-party sellers run wild.

title: English Teenager Finds Bronze Age Ax Using a Metal Detector
content: On her third day out with a metal detector, Milly Hardwick, 13, found a hoard of items from more than 3,000 years ago. “We were just laughing our heads off,” she said.

title: Recipe Plagiarism and Buying a High School: The Week in Narrated Articles
content: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

title: Talking About the Best Books of 2021
content: On a special episode of the podcast, taped live, editors from The New York Times Book Review discuss this year’s outstanding fiction and nonfiction.

title: Israeli Company’s Spyware Is Used to Target U.S. Embassy Employees in Africa
content: The hack is the first known case of the spyware, known as Pegasus, being used against American officials.

more_info.byline: By Katie Benner, David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes

title: How a Cream Cheese Shortage Is Affecting N.Y.C. Bagel Shops
content: Supply chain problems that have hit businesses across the country now threaten a quintessential New York treat.

title: Belgian Port City Grapples With a Flood of Cocaine
content: Antwerp has become the main port of entry into Europe for the drug, which is being blamed for a surge of violence that has prompted some Belgian officials to call for a war on drugs.

title: Dr. Sherif R. Zaki, Acclaimed Disease Detective, Dies at 65
content: He helped identify numerous viruses, including Covid-19, as well as the bioterrorism attack that spread anthrax in 2001.

org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Federal Scrutiny of Cuomo Widens to His Office’s Treatment of Women
content: The Justice Department opened an inquiry into reports of sexual harassment and retaliation in the former governor’s administration.

title: Takeaways from the fifth day of Ghislaine Maxwell’s trial.

more_info.byline: By Rebecca Davis O’Brien and Colin Moynihan

title: At Least One Dead as Volcano Erupts in Indonesia, Spewing Ash Cloud
content: Dozens more suffered burns as lava flowed from the eruption of Mount Semeru, on the island of Java.

more_info.byline: By Aina J. Khan and Muktita Suhartono

title: LaMarr Hoyt, Pitcher Whose Star Shone Brightly but Briefly, Dies at 66
content: He won the 1983 Cy Young Award as the American League’s leading pitcher, but an injury and troubles with drugs and the law ended his career prematurely.

title: Money Found by Plumber at Joel Osteen’s Church Is Tied to 2014 Burglary, Police Say
content: The discovery was revealed when the plumber called into a Houston radio show on Thursday.

title: Congo Ousts Mining Leader in a Cloud of Corruption Claims
content: The country’s president removed Albert Yuma Mulimbi as chairman of the state mining firm. Cobalt in Congo is a crucial resource in the global clean energy revolution.

more_info.byline: By Eric Lipton and Dionne Searcey

title: Our 8 Favorite Books in 2021 for Healthy Living
content: This year’s Well Book List includes advice on how to change behavior, lower anxiety, cope with hardship and heal with poetry.

title: Overcoming Motherhood Imposter Syndrome
content: Casey Wilson learned to trust her parenting instincts after her son received a surprise diagnosis.

title: New Hope for Migraine Sufferers
content: There are now a number of medications that may prevent or alleviate migraines, as well as a wearable nerve-stimulating device that can be activated by a smartphone.

title: Older Singles Have Found a New Way to Partner Up: Living Apart
content: Fearing that a romantic attachment in later life will lead to full-time caregiving, many couples are choosing commitment without sharing a home.

title: Weekly Health Quiz: Poop, Pie and a Heart-Healthy Diet
content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

title: Denzel Washington, Man on Fire
content: The actor never leans in — he’s all in. And in his latest, “Macbeth,” conjured by Joel Coen, he is as sharp and deadly as a dagger.

title: Ron Cephas Jones Has Something to Prove Again
content: The Emmy-winning “This Is Us” actor received a double-lung transplant after a secret battle with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Now he’s back onstage in “Clyde’s” on Broadway.

title: Can I Confront My Dad About His Possibly Secret Relationship?
content: A reader asks for advice on talking to her father about his new romantic life.

title: They Adapted ‘Mrs. Doubtfire,’ and Their Personal Beliefs
content: Wayne and Karey Kirkpatrick have come a long way from their beginnings in Christian rock, but they’re glad to be creating a family-friendly musical comedy.

title: Kodi Smit-McPhee on Quiet Confidence, Chronic Pain and ‘The Power of the Dog’
content: The 25-year-old Aussie delivers a scene-stealing performance as Peter, a bookish boy and aspiring doctor who’s more than he seems.
